Gap Analysis for Operating IPv6-Only MPLS Networks
Abstract
contents.ja: 抽象

contents.text: This document reviews the Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) protocol suite in the context of IPv6 and identifies gaps that must be addressed in order to allow MPLS-related protocols and applications to be used with IPv6-only networks. This document is intended to focus on gaps in the standards defining the MPLS suite, and is not intended to highlight particular vendor implementations (or lack thereof) in the context of IPv6-only MPLS functionality.
contents.ja: この文書は、IPv6のコンテキストでマルチプロトコルラベルスイッチング（MPLS）プロトコルスイートをレビューし、MPLS関連のプロトコルおよびアプリケーションがIPv6のみのネットワークで使用できるようにするために取り組まなければならないのギャップを識別します。この文書では、MPLSスイートを定義する基準のギャップに焦点を当てることを意図され、そしてIPv6専用MPLS機能のコンテキストにおける特定のベンダの実装（またはその欠如）を強調することを意図していません。

contents.text: In the data plane, MPLS fully supports IPv6, and MPLS labeled packets can be carried over IPv6 packets in a variety of encapsulations. However, support for IPv6 among MPLS control-plane protocols, MPLS applications, MPLS Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (OAM), and MIB modules is mixed, with some protocols having major gaps. For most major gaps, work is in progress to upgrade the relevant protocols.
contents.ja: データプレーンにおいて、MPLSは、完全にIPv6をサポートし、MPLSラベル付きパケットは、カプセル化の様々なIPv6パケットを介して搬送することができます。しかし、MPLSコントロールプレーンプロトコル、MPLSアプリケーション、MPLS運用、管理、および保守（OAM）、およびMIBモジュール間IPv6のサポートは、主要なギャップを有するいくつかのプロトコルを用いて、混合されます。ほとんどの主要なギャップのために、仕事は、関連するプロトコルをアップグレードするために進行中です。

1. Introduction
contents.ja: 1. はじめに

contents.text: IPv6 [RFC2460] is an integral part of modern network deployments. At the time when this document was written, the majority of these IPv6 deployments were using dual-stack implementations, where IPv4 and IPv6 are supported equally on many or all of the network nodes, and single-stack primarily referred to IPv4-only devices. Dual-stack deployments provide a useful margin for protocols and features that are not currently capable of operating solely over IPv6, because they can continue using IPv4 as necessary. However, as IPv6 deployment and usage becomes more pervasive, and IPv4 exhaustion begins driving changes in address consumption behaviors, there is an increasing likelihood that many networks will need to start operating some or all of their network nodes either as primarily IPv6 (most functions use IPv6, a few legacy features use IPv4), or as IPv6-only (no IPv4 provisioned on the device). This transition toward IPv6-only operation exposes any gaps where features, protocols, or implementations are still reliant on IPv4 for proper function. To that end, and in the spirit of the recommendation in RFC 6540 [RFC6540] that implementations need to stop requiring IPv4 for proper and complete function, this document reviews the MPLS protocol suite in the context of IPv6 and identifies gaps that must be addressed in order to allow MPLS-related protocols and applications to be used with IPv6-only networks and networks that are primarily IPv6 (hereafter referred to as IPv6-primary). This document is intended to focus on gaps in the standards defining the MPLS suite, and not to highlight particular vendor implementations (or lack thereof) in the context of IPv6-only MPLS functionality.

contents.text: 2. Use Case
contents.ja: 2.ユースケース

contents.text: This section discusses some drivers for ensuring that MPLS completely supports IPv6-only operation. It is not intended to be a comprehensive discussion of all potential use cases, but rather a discussion of one use case to provide context and justification to undertake such a gap analysis.
contents.ja: このセクションでは、IPv6のみの操作をサポートすることが完全にMPLS確保するためのいくつかのドライバについて説明します。すべての潜在的な使用ケースの包括的な説明ではなく、そのようなギャップ分析を行うことコンテキストと正当化を提供するために、1つのユースケースの説明を意図するものではありません。

contents.text: IP convergence is continuing to drive new classes of devices to begin communicating via IP. Examples of such devices could include set-top boxes for IP video distribution, cell tower electronics (macro or micro cells), infrastructure Wi-Fi access points, and devices for machine-to-machine (M2M) or Internet of Things (IoT) applications. In some cases, these classes of devices represent a very large deployment base, on the order of thousands or even millions of devices network-wide. The scale of these networks, coupled with the increasingly overlapping use of RFC 1918 [RFC1918] address space within the average network and the lack of globally routable IPv4 space available for long-term growth, begins to drive the need for many of the endpoints in this network to be managed solely via IPv6. Even if these devices are carrying some IPv4 user data, it is often encapsulated in another protocol such that the communication between the endpoint and its upstream devices can be IPv6-only without impacting support for IPv4 on user data. As the number of devices to manage increases, the operator is compelled to move to IPv6. Depending on the MPLS features required, it is plausible to assume that the (existing) MPLS network will need to be extended to these IPv6-only devices.

contents.text: Additionally, as the impact of IPv4 exhaustion becomes more acute, more and more aggressive IPv4 address reclamation measures will be justified. Many networks are likely to focus on preserving their remaining IPv4 addresses for revenue-generating customers so that legacy support for IPv4 can be maintained as long as necessary. As a result, it may be appropriate for some or all of the network infrastructure, including MPLS Label Switching Routers (LSRs) and Label Edge Routers (LERs), to have its IPv4 addresses reclaimed and transition toward IPv6-only operation.

contents.text: 3. Gap Analysis
contents.ja: 3.ギャップ分析

contents.text: This gap analysis aims to answer the question of what fails when one attempts to use MPLS features on a network of IPv6-only devices. The baseline assumption for this analysis is that some endpoints, as well as Label Switching Routers (Provider Edge (PE) and Provider (P) routers), only have IPv6 transport available and need to support the full suite of MPLS features defined as of the time of this document's writing at parity with the support on an IPv4 network. This is necessary whether they are enabled via the Label Distribution Protocol (LDP) [RFC5036], RSVP - Traffic Engineering (RSVP-TE) [RFC3209], or Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) [RFC3107], and whether they are encapsulated in MPLS [RFC3032], IP [RFC4023], Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) [RFC4023], or Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol Version 3 (L2TPv3) [RFC4817]. It is important when evaluating these gaps to distinguish between user data and control-plane data, because while this document is focused on IPv6-only operation, it is quite likely that some amount of the user payload data being carried in the IPv6-only MPLS network will still be IPv4.

contents.text: A note about terminology: Gaps identified by this document are characterized as "Major" or "Minor". Major gaps refer to significant changes necessary in one or more standards to address the gap due to existing standards language having either missing functionality for IPv6-only operation or explicit language requiring the use of IPv4 with no IPv6 alternatives defined. Minor gaps refer to changes necessary primarily to clarify existing standards language. Usually these changes are needed in order to explicitly codify IPv6 support in places where it is either implicit or omitted today, but the omission is unlikely to prevent IPv6-only operation.

The encapsulations of MPLS in IP and GRE, as well as MPLS over L2TPv3, support IPv6. See Section 3 of RFC 4023 [RFC4023] and Section 2 of RFC 4817 [RFC4817], respectively.

contents.text: 3.2.1. Label Distribution Protocol (LDP)
contents.ja: 3.2.1. ラベル配布プロトコル（LDP）

contents.text: The Label Distribution Protocol (LDP) [RFC5036] defines a set of procedures for distribution of labels between Label Switching Routers that can use the labels for forwarding traffic. While LDP was designed to use an IPv4 or dual-stack IP network, it has a number of deficiencies that prevent it from working in an IPv6-only network. LDP-IPv6 [LDP-IPv6] highlights some of the deficiencies when LDP is enabled in IPv6-only or dual-stack networks and specifies appropriate protocol changes. These deficiencies are related to Label Switched Path (LSP) mapping, LDP identifiers, LDP discovery, LDP session establishment, next-hop address, and LDP Time To Live (TTL) security [RFC5082] [RFC6720].

contents.text: 3.2.2. Multipoint LDP (mLDP)
contents.ja: 3.2.2. マルチLDP（MLDP）

contents.text: Multipoint LDP (mLDP) is a set of extensions to LDP for setting up Point-to-Multipoint (P2MP) and Multipoint-to-Multipoint (MP2MP) LSPs. These extensions are specified in RFC 6388 [RFC6388]. In terms of IPv6-only gap analysis, mLDP has two identified areas of interest:
contents.ja: マルチLDP（MLDP）は、ポイントツーマルチポイント（P2MP）と多対多（MP2MP）LSPを設定するためのLDPの拡張セットです。これらの拡張機能は、RFC 6388 [RFC6388]で指定されています。 IPv6のみのギャップ分析の観点で、MLDPは、目的の2つ同定された領域を有します。

contents.text: 1. LDP Control Plane: Since mLDP uses the LDP control plane to discover and establish sessions with the peer, it shares the same gaps as LDP (Section 3.2.1) with regards to control plane (discovery, transport, and session establishment) in an IPv6-only network.
contents.ja: 1. LDPコントロールプレーンは：MLDPが発見とピアとのセッションを確立するために、LDP制御プレーンを使用するので、それは同じギャップを共有するような面を制御するために関して（発見、輸送、及びセッション確立）のあるLDP（3.2.1） IPv6のみのネットワーク。

contents.text: 2. Multipoint (MP) Forwarding Equivalence Class (FEC) Root Address: mLDP defines its own MP FECs and rules, different from LDP, to map MP LSPs. An mLDP MP FEC contains a Root Address field that is an IP address in IP networks. The current specification allows specifying the root address according to the Address Family Identifier (AFI), and hence covers both IPv4 or IPv6 root addresses, requiring no extension to support IPv6-only MP LSPs. The root address is used by each LSR participating in an MP LSP setup such that root address reachability is resolved by doing a table lookup against the root address to find corresponding upstream neighbor(s). This will pose a problem if an MP LSP traverses IPv4-only and IPv6-only nodes in a dual-stack network on the way to the root node.
contents.ja: 2.マルチポイント（MP）転送等価クラス（FEC）ルートアドレス：MLDPは、MPのLSPをマッピングするために、LDPとは異なる独自のMPのFEC及び規則を定義します。 MLDP MP FECは、IPネットワーク内のIPアドレスであるルート・アドレス・フィールドが含まれています。現在の仕様では、IPv6のみのMPのLSPをサポートするために拡張子を必要としない、アドレスファミリ識別子（AFI）に従ってルートアドレスを指定することができ、ひいてはIPv4またはIPv6ルートアドレスの両方をカバーします。ルートアドレスは、ルートアドレスの到達可能性は、上流隣接（S）に対応する見つけるためにルートアドレスに対してテーブルルックアップを行うことによって解決されるように、MP LSPセットアップに参加する各LSRによって使用されます。 MP LSPがルートノードへの道上のデュアルスタックネットワークにおけるIPv4のみとIPv6専用ノードを通過する場合、これは問題を提起します。

contents.text: Assume R1 to be a leaf node for a P2MP LSP rooted at R6 (root node). R1 uses R6's IPv4 address as the root address in MP FEC. As the MP LSP signaling proceeds from R1 to R6, the MP LSP setup will fail on the first IPv6-only transit/branch LSRs (R3) when trying to find IPv4 root address reachability. RFC 6512 [RFC6512] defines a recursive-FEC solution and procedures for mLDP when the backbone (transit/ branch) LSRs have no route to the root. The proposed solution is defined for a BGP-free core in a VPN environment, but a similar concept can be used/extended to solve the above issue of the IPv6-only backbone receiving an MP FEC element with an IPv4 address. The solution will require a border LSR (the one that is sitting on the border of an IPv4/IPv6 island (namely, R2 and R5 in this example)) to translate an IPv4 root address to an equivalent IPv6 address (and vice versa) through procedures similar to RFC 6512.

contents.text: RSVP-TE [RFC3209] defines a set of procedures and enhancements to establish LSP tunnels that can be automatically routed away from network failures, congestion, and bottlenecks. RSVP-TE allows establishing an LSP for an IPv4 or IPv6 prefix, thanks to its LSP_TUNNEL_IPv6 object and subobjects.

contents.text: 3.2.4. Path Computation Element (PCE)
contents.ja: 3.2.4. 経路計算エレメント（PCE）

contents.text: The Path Computation Element (PCE) defined in RFC 4655 [RFC4655] is an entity that is capable of computing a network path or route based on a network graph and applying computational constraints. A Path Computation Client (PCC) may make requests to a PCE for paths to be computed. The PCE Communication Protocol (PCEP) is designed as a communication protocol between PCCs and PCEs for path computations and is defined in RFC 5440 [RFC5440].
contents.ja: RFC 4655 [RFC4655]で定義された経路計算エレメント（PCE）は、ネットワークグラフに基づいてネットワークパスまたはルートを計算し、計算上の制約を適用することが可能なエンティティです。経路を計算するための経路計算クライアント（PCC）は、PCEに要求を行うことができます。 PCE通信プロトコル（PCEP）は、パス計算のためのPCCとPCEとの間の通信プロトコルとして設計されており、RFC 5440 [RFC5440]で定義されています。

contents.text: The PCEP specification [RFC5440] is defined for both IPv4 and IPv6 with support for PCE discovery via an IGP (OSPF [RFC5088] or IS-IS [RFC5089]) using both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses. Note that PCEP uses identical encoding of subobjects, as in RSVP-TE defined in RFC 3209 [RFC3209] that supports both IPv4 and IPv6.

contents.text: The extensions to PCEP to support confidentiality [RFC5520], route exclusions [RFC5521], monitoring [RFC5886], and P2MP TE LSPs [RFC6006] have support for both IPv4 and IPv6.

contents.text: 3.3.1. Layer 2 Virtual Private Network (L2VPN)
contents.ja: 3.3.1. レイヤ2仮想プライベートネットワーク（L2VPN）

contents.text: L2VPN [RFC4664] specifies two fundamentally different kinds of Layer 2 VPN services that a service provider could offer to a customer: Virtual Private Wire Service (VPWS) and Virtual Private LAN Service (VPLS). RFC 4447 [RFC4447] and RFC 4762 [RFC4762] specify the LDP protocol changes to instantiate VPWS and VPLS services, respectively, in an MPLS network using LDP as the signaling protocol. This is complemented by RFC 6074 [RFC6074], which specifies a set of procedures for instantiating L2VPNs (e.g., VPWS, VPLS) using BGP as a discovery protocol and LDP, as well as L2TPv3, as a signaling protocol. RFC 4761 [RFC4761] and RFC 6624 [RFC6624] specify BGP protocol changes to instantiate VPLS and VPWS services in an MPLS network, using BGP for both discovery and signaling.
contents.ja: 仮想専用線サービス（VPWS）と仮想プライベートLANサービス（VPLS）：L2VPN [RFC4664]は、サービスプロバイダが顧客に提供することができ、レイヤ2 VPNサービスの根本的に異なる二つの種類を指定します。 RFC 4447 [RFC4447]及びRFC 4762 [RFC4762]のシグナリングプロトコルとしてLDPを使用して、MPLSネットワークにおいて、それぞれ、VPWSおよびVPLSサービスをインスタンス化するためにLDPプロトコルの変更を指定します。これは、シグナリングプロトコルとして、RFC 6074発見プロトコルおよびLDPとしてBGPを使用して（例えば、VPWS、VPLS）のL2VPNをインスタンス化するための手順のセットを指定する[RFC6074]、並びにのL2TPv3によって補完されます。 RFC 4761 [RFC4761]及びRFC 6624 [RFC6624]の発見とシグナリングの両方のためにBGPを使用して、MPLSネットワークでVPLSとVPWSサービスをインスタンス化するためにBGPプロトコルの変更を指定します。

contents.text: In an IPv6-only MPLS network, use of L2VPN represents a connection of Layer 2 islands over an IPv6 MPLS core, and very few changes are necessary to support operation over an IPv6-only network. The L2VPN signaling protocol is either BGP or LDP in an MPLS network, and both can run directly over IPv6 core infrastructure as well as IPv6 edge devices. RFC 6074 [RFC6074] is the only RFC that appears to have a gap for IPv6-only operation. In its discovery procedures (Sections 3.2.2 and 6 of RFC 6074 [RFC6074]), it suggests encoding PE IP addresses in the Virtual Switching Instance ID (VSI-ID), which is encoded in Network Layer Reachability Information (NLRI) and should not exceed 12 bytes (to differentiate its AFI/SAFI (Subsequent Address Family Identifier) encoding from RFC 4761). This means that a PE IP address cannot be an IPv6 address. Also, in its signaling procedures (Section 3.2.3 of RFC 6074 [RFC6074]), it suggests encoding PE_addr in the Source Attachment Individual Identifier (SAII) and the Target Attachment Individual Identifier (TAII), which are limited to 32 bits (AII Type=1) at the moment.
contents.ja: IPv6のみのMPLSネットワークでは、L2VPNの使用は、IPv6 MPLSコア上のレイヤの接続2つの島を表し、そして非常にいくつかの変更は、IPv6のみのネットワークでの動作をサポートするために必要です。 L2VPNシグナリングプロトコルは、MPLSネットワークにおけるBGP又はLDPのいずれかであり、両方は、IPv6コアインフラストラクチャと同様のIPv6エッジデバイス上で直接実行することができます。 RFC 6074 [RFC6074]はIPv6のみの操作のためのギャップを有するように見えるだけRFCです。その発見手順（セクション3.2.2およびRFC 6074の6 [RFC6074]）には、ネットワーク層到達可能性情報（NLRI）で符号化とすべきである仮想スイッチングインスタンスID（VSI-ID）にPE IPアドレスをコード示唆します12バイト（RFC 4761からのAFI / SAFI（次のアドレスファミリー識別子）エンコーディングを区別するため）を超えません。これは、PEのIPアドレスがIPv6アドレスではないことを意味します。また、そのシグナリング手順（RFC 6074のセクション3.2.3 [RFC6074]）には、ソース添付個体識別子（SAII）と32ビット（AIIに制限されているターゲットアタッチメント個体識別子（TAII）にPE_addrをコード示唆します現時点ではタイプ= 1）。

contents.text: RFC 6073 [RFC6073] defines the new LDP Pseudowire (PW) Switching Point PE TLV, which supports IPv4 and IPv6.

contents.ja: 3.3.2. レイヤ3仮想プライベートネットワーク（L3VPN）

contents.text: RFC 4364 [RFC4364] defines a method by which a Service Provider may use an IP backbone to provide IP VPNs for its customers. The following use cases arise in the context of this gap analysis:

contents.text: Now assume that one of the hosts sends an IPv4 packet to the other. However, the packet's TTL expires on an LSP interior router. In this case, however, the LSP interior router is not IPv4-aware. It cannot parse the original IPv4 datagram, nor can it send an IPv4 message. So, no ICMP message is delivered to the source. Some specific ICMP extensions, in particular, ICMP extensions for interface and next-hop identification [RFC5837], restrict the address family of address information included in an Interface Information Object to the same one as the ICMP (see Section 4.5 of RFC 5837). While these extensions are not MPLS specific, they can be used with MPLS packets carrying IP datagrams. This has no implications for IPv6-only environments.

contents.text: 3.4.2. Label Switched Path Ping (LSP Ping)

contents.text: The LSP Ping mechanism defined in RFC 4379 [RFC4379] is specified to work with IPv6. Specifically, the Target FEC Stacks include both IPv4 and IPv6 versions of all FECs (see Section 3.2 of RFC 4379). The only exceptions are the Pseudowire FECs, which are later specified for IPv6 in RFC 6829 [RFC6829]. The multipath information also includes IPv6 encodings (see Section 3.3.1 of RFC 4379).
contents.ja: RFC 4379 [RFC4379]で定義されたLSPピング機構は、IPv6で動作するように指定されています。具体的には、ターゲットFECスタックは、すべてのFEC（RFC 4379のセクション3.2を参照）のIPv4とIPv6の両方のバージョンを含みます。唯一の例外は、後にRFC 6829 [RFC6829]でIPv6用に指定された疑似回線のFECです。マルチパス情報は、IPv6のエンコーディングを（RFC 4379のセクション3.3.1を参照）が含まれています。

contents.text: LSP Ping packets are UDP packets over either IPv4 or IPv6 (see Section 4.3 of RFC 4379). However, for IPv6 the destination IP address is a (randomly chosen) IPv6 address from the range 0:0:0:0:0:FFFF:127/104; that is, using an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address. This is a transitional mechanism that should not bleed into IPv6-only networks, as [IPv4-MAPPED] explains. The issue is that the MPLS LSP Ping mechanism needs a range of loopback IP addresses to be used as destination addresses to exercise Equal Cost Multiple Path (ECMP), but the IPv6 address architecture specifies a single address (::1/128) for loopback. A mechanism to achieve this was proposed in [LOOPBACK-PREFIX].
contents.ja: LSP pingパケットをIPv4またはIPv6のいずれかを超えるUDPパケット（RFC 4379のセクション4.3を参照）があります。しかし、IPv6の宛先IPアドレス範囲からの（ランダムに選択）IPv6アドレスは0：0：0：0：0：FFFF：104分の127。すなわち、IPv4マップIPv6アドレスを使用して、です。 [IPv4マップ]、これは、IPv6のみのネットワークにブリードしないべき遷移メカニズムで説明しています。問題は、ループバック用のMPLS LSP pingのメカニズムは、イコールコストマルチパス（ECMP）を行使する宛先アドレスとして使用するループバックIPアドレスの範囲を必要とするが、IPv6アドレスアーキテクチャは、単一のアドレス（:: 1/128）を指定していることです。これを達成するメカニズムは、[ループバックPREFIX]に提案されました。

contents.text: Additionally, RFC 4379 does not define the value to be used in the IPv6 Router Alert option (RAO). For IPv4 RAO, a value of zero is used. However, there is no equivalent value for IPv6 RAO. This gap needs to be fixed to be able to use LSP Ping in IPv6 networks. Further details on this gap are captured, along with a proposed solution, in [IPv6-RAO].
contents.ja: また、RFC 4379には、IPv6ルータアラートオプション（RAO）で使用される値を定義していません。 IPv4のRAOのために、ゼロの値が使用されます。ただし、IPv6 RAOには同等の価値はありません。このギャップは、IPv6ネットワークでLSPピングを使用できるように固定する必要があります。この隙間の詳細は、[IPv6の-RAO]で提案された解決策とともに、捕捉されます。

contents.text: Another gap is that the mechanisms described in RFC 4379 may fail when tunneling IPv4 traffic over an LSP that is supported by IPv6-only infrastructure.
contents.ja: 別のギャップは、IPv6のみのインフラストラクチャによってサポートされているLSP上のIPv4トラフィックをトンネリングするときRFC 4379で説明されたメカニズムが失敗する可能性があることです。

contents.text: Assume the following:
contents.ja: 次のことを想定します。

contents.text: o LSP Ping is operating in traceroute mode over an MPLS LSP.
contents.ja: O LSP pingは、MPLS LSP上でトレースルートモードで動作しています。

contents.text: o The two routers that terminate the LSP run dual stack.
contents.ja: LSPを終了する2台のルータがデュアルスタックを実行してoを。

contents.text: o The LSP interior routers run IPv6 only.
contents.ja: O LSPの内部ルータはIPv6のみを実行します。

contents.text: o The LSP is signaled over IPv6.
contents.ja: O LSPは、IPv6の上にシグナリングされます。

contents.text: Packets will expire at LSP interior routers. According to RFC 4379, the interior router must parse the IPv4 Echo Request and then send an IPv4 Echo Reply. However, the LSP interior router is not IPv4-aware. It cannot parse the IPv4 Echo Request, nor can it send an IPv4 Echo Reply. So, no reply is sent.
contents.ja: パケットは、LSPの内部ルータで期限切れになります。 RFC 4379によると、内部ルータは、IPv4エコー要求を解析して、IPv4のエコー応答を送信する必要があります。しかし、LSPの内部ルータは、IPv4に対応していません。これは、IPv4のエコー要求を解析することができない、またそれは、IPv4エコー応答を送信することができます。だから、何の返事は送信されません。

contents.text: The mechanism described in RFC 4379 also does not sufficiently explain the behavior in certain IPv6-specific scenarios. For example, RFC 4379 defines the K value as 28 octets when the Address Family is set to IPv6 Unnumbered, but it doesn't describe how to carry a 32-bit LSR Router ID in the 128-bit Downstream IP Address field.
contents.ja: RFC 4379で説明したメカニズムも十分に特定のIPv6固有のシナリオでの動作を説明していません。例えば、RFC 4379には、アドレス・ファミリーがIPv6番号なしに設定されている28個のオクテットとしてK値を定義し、それは128ビット下流IPアドレスフィールドに32ビットのLSRルータIDを搬送する方法を説明しません。

contents.text: Gap: Major; LSP Ping uses IPv4-mapped IPv6 addresses. IP version mismatches may cause dropped messages and unclear mapping from the LSR Router ID to Downstream IP Address.
contents.ja: ギャップ：主な; LSP pingは、IPv4射影IPv6アドレスを使用しています。 IPバージョンの不一致が発生することがあり川下IPアドレスにLSRルータIDからのメッセージや不明瞭なマッピングを落としました。

contents.text: 3.4.3. Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD)
contents.ja: 3.4.3. 双方向フォワーディング検出（BFD）

contents.text: The BFD specification for MPLS LSPs [RFC5884] is defined for IPv4, as well as IPv6, versions of MPLS FECs (see Section 3.1 of RFC 5884). Additionally, the BFD packet is encapsulated over UDP and specified to run over both IPv4 and IPv6 (see Section 7 of RFC 5884).
contents.ja: MPLSのLSP [RFC5884]のための仕様は、IPv4で定義されているBFD、ならびにIPv6の、MPLSのFECのバージョン（RFC 5884のセ​​クション3.1を参照）。また、BFDパケットは（RFC 5884のセ​​クション7を参照）UDP上でカプセル化し、IPv4とIPv6の両方で実行するように指定されています。

contents.text: Gap: None.
contents.ja: ギャップ：なし。

contents.text: 3.4.4. Pseudowire OAM
contents.ja: 3.4.4. スードワイヤOAM

contents.text: The OAM specifications for MPLS Pseudowires define usage for both IPv4 and IPv6. Specifically, VCCV [RFC5085] can carry IPv4 or IPv6 OAM packets (see Sections 5.1.1 and 5.2.1 of RFC 5085), and VCCV for BFD [RFC5885] also defines an IPv6 encapsulation (see Section 3.2 of RFC 5885).
contents.ja: MPLSスードワイヤのためのOAMの仕様は、IPv4とIPv6の両方の使用を定義します。具体的には、VCCV [RFC5085]はBFDのIPv4またはIPv6 OAMパケット（セクション5.1.1およびRFC 5085の5.2.1を参照）、およびVCCVを運ぶことができる[RFC5885]ものIPv6カプセル化（RFC 5885のセクション3.2を参照）を定義します。

contents.text: Additionally, for LSP Ping for pseudowires, the Pseudowire FECs are specified for IPv6 in RFC 6829 [RFC6829].
contents.ja: また、疑似回線用LSPピングのために、疑似回線のFECは、RFC 6829 [RFC6829]でIPv6用に指定されています。

contents.text: Gap: None.
contents.ja: ギャップ：なし。

contents.text: 3.4.5. MPLS Transport Profile (MPLS-TP) OAM
contents.ja: 3.4.5.  MPLSトランスポートプロファイル（MPLS-TP）OAM

contents.text: As with MPLS-TP, MPLS-TP OAM [RFC6371] does not require IP or existing MPLS OAM functions and should not be affected by operation on an IPv6-only network. Therefore, this is out of scope for this document but is included for completeness. Although not required, MPLS-TP can use IP.

contents.text: Gap: None. MPLS-TP OAM does not require IP.
contents.ja: ギャップ：なし。 MPLS-TP OAMは、IPを必要としません。

contents.text: 3.5. MIB Modules
contents.ja: 3.5.  MIBモジュール

contents.text: RFC 3811 [RFC3811] defines the textual conventions for MPLS. These lack support for IPv6 in defining MplsExtendedTunnelId and MplsLsrIdentifier. These textual conventions are used in the MPLS-TE MIB specification [RFC3812], the GMPLS-TE MIB specification [RFC4802] and the FRR extension [RFC6445]. "Definitions of Textual Conventions (TCs) for Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) Management" [MPLS-TC] tries to resolve this gap by marking this textual convention as obsolete.
contents.ja: RFC 3811 [RFC3811]はMPLSのためのテキストの表記法を定義します。これらはMplsExtendedTunnelIdとMplsLsrIdentifierを定義におけるIPv6のサポートを欠いています。これらのテキストの表記法は、GMPLS-TE MIB仕様[RFC4802]とFRR拡張[RFC6445]、[RFC3812] MPLS-TE MIB仕様で使用されています。 「（MPLS）管理をマルチプロトコルラベルスイッチングのためのテキストの表記法（TCS）の定義」[MPLS-TC]は古いものとして、このテキストの表記法をマークすることによって、このギャップを解決しようとします。

contents.text: The other MIB specifications for LSR [RFC3813], LDP [RFC3815], and TE [RFC4220] have support for both IPv4 and IPv6.
contents.ja: LSR [RFC3813]、LDP [RFC3815]、およびTE [RFC4220]のための他のMIB仕様は、IPv4とIPv6の両方をサポートしています。

contents.text: Lastly, RFC 4990 [RFC4990] discusses how to handle IPv6 sources and destinations in the MPLS and GMPLS-TE MIB modules. In particular, Section 8 of RFC 4990 [RFC4990] describes a method of defining or monitoring an LSP tunnel using the MPLS-TE and GMPLS-TE MIB modules, working around some of the limitations in RFC 3811 [RFC3811].
contents.ja: 最後に、RFC 4990 [RFC4990]はMPLSとGMPLS-TE MIBモジュールでのIPv6ソースと宛先を処理する方法について説明します。具体的には、RFC 4990 [RFC4990]のセクション8は、定義またはMPLS-TEやGMPLS-TE MIBモジュールを使用して、LSPトンネルを監視し、RFC 3811 [RFC3811]の制限のいくつかを回避作業の方法を記載しています。

contents.text: Gap: Minor; Section 8 of RFC 4990 [RFC4990] describes a method to handle IPv6 addresses in the MPLS-TE [RFC3812] and GMPLS-TE [RFC4802] MIB modules. Work underway to update RFC 3811 via [MPLS-TC], may also need to update RFC 3812, RFC 4802, and RFC 6445, which depend on it.

contents.text: 4. Gap Summary
contents.ja: 4.ギャップまとめ

contents.text: This document has reviewed a wide variety of MPLS features and protocols to determine their suitability for use on IPv6-only or IPv6-primary networks. While some parts of the MPLS suite will function properly without additional changes, gaps have been identified in others that will need to be addressed with follow-on work. This section will summarize those gaps, along with pointers to any work in progress to address them. Note that because the referenced documents are works in progress and do not have consensus at the time of this document's publication, there could be other solutions proposed at a future time, and the pointers in this document should not be considered normative in any way. Additionally, work in progress on new features that use MPLS protocols will need to ensure that those protocols support operation on IPv6-only or IPv6-primary networks, or explicitly identify any dependencies on existing gaps that, once resolved, will allow proper IPv6-only operation.
